html:
Etymology[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *per- (“go, traverse”), either as *pr̥-to- or *por-to-, perhaps from a noun having the sense of "way" or "passage". Related to Ancient Greek πείρω (peírō, “I pierce, traverse”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈpor.toː/, [ˈpɔr.t̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈpor.to/, [ˈpɔr.t̪ɔ]
  • Audio (Classical)
    		(file)

Verb[edit]

portō (present infinitive portāre, perfect active portāvī, supine portātum); first conjugation

  1. I carry, bear
  2. I convey, bring

Synonyms[edit]

  • (carry, bear): ferō, gerō, vehō
  • (convey, bring): vehō

Derived terms[edit]

  • apportō
  • asportō
  • comportō
  • deportō
  • exportō
  • importō
  • importūnus
  • portābilis
  • opportō
  • opportūnus
  • portātor
  • reportō
  • supportō
  • trānsportō

Descendants[edit]

  • Aromanian: portu, purtari
  • Asturian: portar
  • Catalan: portar
  • Dalmatian: portur
  • French: porter
  • Friulian: puartâ
  • Galician: portar
  • Istriot: portà
  • Italian: portare
  • Ladin: porter
  • Neapolitan: purtà
  • Occitan: portar
  • Portuguese: portar
  • Romanian: purta, purtare
  • Romansch: purtar, porter, portar
  • Sardinian: poltare, portai, portare, potai
  • Sicilian: purtari
  • Spanish: portar
  • Venetian: portar

References[edit]

  • porto in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • porto in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • porto in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • (ambiguous) to barricade the gates: portas obstruere (B. G. 5. 50)
    • (ambiguous) to break down the gates: portas refringere
  • porto in Ramminger, Johann (accessed 16 July 2016) Neulateinische Wortliste: Ein Wörterbuch des Lateinischen von Petrarca bis 1700‎[2], pre-publication website, 2005-2016
